intro: Lycianthes heterochondra, commonly known as the Mexican nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of South America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like tomatoes and potatoes. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. Its fruits are typically small, green berries that turn red when ripe, and they contain seeds that are dispersed by animals. The plant is often found in dry, open habitats and is adapted to thrive in warm, arid conditions.
